report_title: Direct Selling of Jewelry & Accessories in the US
executive_summary: The traditional direct selling model of face-to-face exchanges between a seller and a customer has struggled against a quickly evolving retail market. More than ever, consumers purchase jewelry and accessories by picking up their phones and swiping between options. Increasingly time-poor consumers value the quick convenience of an online sale, while the ability to compare styles and prices leave them with the perception they've gotten the best deal. COVID-19's disruption to the retail space has only accelerated this trend.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Direct Selling of Jewelry & Accessories in the US
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: At the same time, consumers have flocked to on-trend, low-cost options at fast fashion retailers. Even as consumers spend robustly on jewelry and accessories post-COVID, a competitive and saturated market leaves little space for direct selling. In all, industry-wide revenue declined at a CAGR of 5.5% to an estimated $492.0 million over the past five years, including an expected drop of 2.9% in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online Retail is Killing the Traditional Direct Selling Model
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Evolving consumer trends have left out direct selling. Rapidly expanding e-commerce sales have siphoned sales as consumers value convenience, broader product selections and the ability to compare reviews and styles over face-to-face interactions. COVID-19's disruption to the retail market accelerated consumers' adoption of online retail, further pressuring the traditional direct selling model.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Savvy Consumers See the Pitfalls of Direct Selling
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) oversees direct selling companies. Recent warnings by the FTC are targeting the business practices of direct sellers and multi-level marketers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Fading Interest in Traditional Direct Selling Will Continue to Wane
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - A yearslong shift away from direct selling will continue moving forward. - Higher incomes and rising consumer spending will slow down how quickly the industry declines compared with previous years, but steep competition will curtail sales. - Consumers will be less interested in the traditional direct selling model as online retail becomes a preferred shopping mode.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer Trends Won't Support Direct Jewelry Selling
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - A strong, renewed interest in local shops following COVID-19 will subside, but more consumers will continue to shop at small, independent stores featuring handmade pieces. Young consumers with growing purchasing power will increasingly align their values to what they buy more than previous generations have. Sustainable and ethically sourced jewelry will be a top concern for this age group.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Direct Sellers Will Embrace Social Media Platforms
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Direct sellers will have to be creative to compete in a saturated market. Social selling through social media platforms like TikTok and Instagram will be commonplace as sellers try to attract new buyers and engage with current ones. Building strong client engagement will be one way for direct sellers to receive referrals, ensure repeat sales and foster a critical competitive advantage.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry rely on a direct sales model, where salespeople are contracted by the company to market the product. Wages are commission based. Companies in this industry supply accessories, including jewelry and watches.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - Per capita disposable income

key_trends: Direct sellers of jewelry and accessories have struggled amid rising external competition
The industry has underperformed the broader direct selling sector over the past five years
Rising external competition has made the industry increasingly price competitive
Rising competition is expected to ultimately keep the industry subdued
Direct sellers that emphasize personalized service will likely perform the strongest
Limited profit and strong external competition are expected to force companies to exit the industry
Online retail is pushing direct sellers out of the jewelry market

market_segmentation.segment_description: Gen Zers are one of the smallest markets for direct sellers. This age group (adults 18 to 24) is college-aged and is likelier to work part-time or are just starting in their careers. Less disposable income leaves these consumers with less money for jewelry and accessories.

Millennials are the second-largest market for direct sellers. Millennials are tech-savvy, so traditional direct selling hasn't remained popular for all adults in this age group. Yet, direct selling has become a popular gig for working millennials and stay-at-home parents to bring in extra cash.

Gen Xers and baby boomers are a critical market for direct sellers of jewelry and accessories. Older adults value face-to-face interactions over digital ones more than their younger counterparts, supporting the traditional direct selling model.

Gen Xers and baby boomers are a critical market for direct sellers of jewelry and accessories. Adults in these age groups have the extra disposable income to spend on jewelry and accessories, so direct sellers will market products specifically for these consumers.

The Silent Generation, or adults 78 and over, is the industry's smallest market. Their conservative spending habits commonly characterize this age cohort, so they're less likely to spend on discretionary items like jewelry or accessories frequently.

products_and_services.product_description: Fine jewelry includes traditional jewelry like rings, necklaces or earrings. Fine jewelry is often crafted from gold, silver or platinum.
Fashion or costume jewelry includes accessories made with non-precious metals, simulated gemstones and other materials.
Direct sellers offer various styles of watches, including fashion, sports and luxury watches.
Precious stone jewelry includes rare or valuable gemstones, like diamonds, rubies, sapphires or emeralds.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Jewelry and accessories are discretionary purchases. So, consumers change the volume and frequency of jewelry purchases depending on their income.

Available substitutes determine demand for direct selling. Consumers have more access than ever to shop and compare different jewelry styles through online retail, on social media or in person at a physical retail location.
Consumer trends influence what jewelry or accessories they'll decide to buy. More than ever, consumers value sustainably and ethically produced jewelry.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Direct sellers of jewelry and accessories don't engage in international trade. Direct sellers can sell products imported into the US, but all trade activity is considered at the manufacturing level.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast houses more than one-quarter of the US population. The region's population density creates more opportunities for direct sellers.
Major metro areas in the region – New York City, Philadelphia and Washington DC – have dense populations where direct sellers can easily access large pools of customers.

California's population (the largest in the US) leads the West to have an above-average number of direct sellers. The remaining states in the West have fewer direct sellers since their populations don't rival California's.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) enforces federal consumer protection laws that prevent fraud, deception and unfair business practices. The FTC enforces regulations specific to direct sellers and multi-level marketing companies.

The Federal Communication Commission (FCC) requires direct sellers with online platforms to inform website visitors how they use their data via a privacy policy. Retailers must abide by the terms of their privacy policy.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Few legal or regulatory barriers prevent new direct selling companies from joining the industry.
Start-up costs are relatively low, as they're limited to inventory and any branding materials.

basis_points.basis_description: The nature of direct selling limits room for differentiation, but successful sellers can stand out through product knowledge or communication skills.
Companies catering products to fit shifting consumer preferences also benefit.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Stella & Dot and Origami Owl are the most prominent names in jewelry and accessory direct selling.
Small, independent jewelry companies round out the market but face competition from leading companies, Amazon and big-box retailers, limiting their sales.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Rising Wage Expenses Aren't Benefiting Direct Sellers
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Wages share of revenue has been rising in recent years, but this doesn't indicate that employees are earning more or labor force shortages are pressuring wages up. Revenue's been declining fast as interest in direct jewelry sales fades. Still, wages and employment have fallen at a lesser pace, so salaries take more revenue now than in previous years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Expenses Shrink Despite Rising Wholesale Prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Despite higher jewelry prices, direct sellers are paying less for inventory in 2023 than in recent years. Supply chain disruptions have caused price fluctuations for raw materials for jewelry, driving price hikes. But, direct sellers are becoming more wary about how much inventory they keep on hand, as quickly changing trends determine what consumers want.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Direct selling of jewelry and accessories isn't capital intensive. For every dollar spent on wages, direct sellers will spend an estimated $0.06 on capital investments in 2023. The nature of direct selling depends on face-to-face interactions between a salesperson and customer, limiting capital requirements. Any software or other tech necessary to track sales and inventory is minimal.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer spending on jewelry is discretionary
volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers change the volume and frequency of jewelry purchases depending on their income. Spending on jewelry generally rises when consumers have more income and feel confident about their financial position. When consumers become more budget-conscious, consumers prioritize spending on necessities like food and bills over jewelry or other accessories.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Direct Selling Continues to Lose Ground
volatility_points.volatility_description: The Federal Trade Commission continues to outline the risks of direct selling or multi-level marketing companies to consumers. Wary consumers are increasingly moving away from direct selling toward online platforms or small, local jewelry shops. Consumers have more access than ever to shop and compare different jewelry styles through online stores or social media, keeping them away from direct sellers. Big-ticket jewelry purchases remain in-store purchases for most consumers.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: The most relevant tech disruption affecting direct sellers of jewelry and accessories is e-commerce.
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Online retail allows consumers to compare different products, search for jewelry styles, look for trends and compare prices easily, so consumers feel less inclined to purchase from a direct seller. E-commerce has completely disrupted the traditional model of direct selling. Disruption is even more prevalent for younger, tech-savvy consumers who are more comfortable online shopping than previous generations. Online retail will continue to impact the broader direct selling industry adversely.

Few tech developments apply to direct selling of jewelry and accessories. The nature of the industry is face-to-face interactions between a seller and a customer, limiting room for tech developments. Online software developed specifically for direct selling does help sellers manage inventory, monitor cashflow and track orders. Social media has also been a proven tool to build brand awareness, attract customers and encourage sales. Still, tech developments don't change the industry's growth trajectory.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry specialize in the sale of jewelry, ranging from fine and fashion jewelry to watches.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Industry products, especially the fine jewelry segment, are viewed as highly discretionary, therefore sales are dependent on low unemployment and high disposable income levels and consumer confidence.

FAQs.question: Have rising input costs negatively affected your company's sales?
FAQs.answer: Gold is a key input into many of the industry's products and as a result when the price of gold increases, the cost of jewelry and watches rises as well. The world price of gold is expected to increase in 2021.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: The majority of employees are considered independent contractors hired by the parent company. Therefore, companies retain these employees by offering them a significant percentage of every sale they make.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: The majority of companies are very small and do not utilize POS systems. However, a few large operators have employed such systems to improve efficiency to manage the availability of products.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Due to the nature of the direct selling industry, companies have been unable to implement automation because employee-to-consumer interaction is essential to the industry.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly affected profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry are subject to very few government regulations and conditions, which include occupational and workplace safety requirements.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Companies impose self-regulation through its trade associations, such as the Direct Selling Association and the World Federation of Direct Selling Associations. The regulations include a code of ethics, which establishes pyramid schemes as illegal.

FAQs.question: How has your company's profit been affected by the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic?
FAQs.answer: Industry profit has declined over the past five years, especially in 2020. The majority of operators were unable to offset costs due to declining revenue streams, squeezing profit margins.

FAQs.question: Retailers have increasingly implemented financing options through third-party applications, such as Afterpay and Klarna. Do you have any challenges with customers paying on time?
FAQs.answer: Many companies offer financing to attract a broader range of customers. For example, financing companies such as Klarna and Afterpay set up payment plans for customers that are typically interest-free if paid on time. Therefore, companies can run into challenges with customers paying on time who opt to finance their purchase instead of pay for it upfront.

FAQs.question: Which niches, if any, do you cater to? How can you diversify your product mix?
FAQs.answer: Having a unique product or access to a niche market gives operators a competitive advantage in the marketplace. Amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, temporary retail closures limited foot traffic. However, companies have been able to remain visible and accessible to customers by offering products online.

FAQs.question: Do you operate on an online or home party basis? How do you set up your products in a visually appealing way?
FAQs.answer: Products must have an appealing and attractive presentation to motivate impulse buying. The at-home business model was significantly impacted by the COVID-19 (coronavirus) outbreak as in-person nonessential businesses were closed temporarily in 2020 and while they have since re-opened, capacity limits have been put in place.

FAQs.question: How many of your clients were referred to you? Do you have any promotions in place that encourage word-of-mouth referrals from existing customers?
FAQs.answer: Word-of-mouth recommendations boost credibility, thus attracting additional consumers. Operators also benefit from advertising campaigns and implementing targeted advertisements to potential customers.

FAQs.question: Do you offer mobile apps to reach your customers? In what other ways can you combat increased internet accessibility?
FAQs.answer: As more consumers opt to comparison shop and purchase items online, demand falls for products sold through direct-selling mediums. E-commerce sales are anticipated to increase strongly in 2021.

FAQs.question: How significantly does consumer confidence affect product demand? What do you do during periods of low consumer confidence?
FAQs.answer: Consumer confidence measures consumers' feelings about present economic conditions and future financial certainty. The consumer confidence index is set to increase in 2021 after a sharp dip in 2020.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor trends in disposable income? How will rising disposable income affect your product pricing?
FAQs.answer: Fluctuations in household disposable income largely influence demand for jewelry and accessories retailed by this industry. Per capita disposable income is anticipated to increase in 2021.
